reviewText:
Do you want one of the most accurate simulations of wrestling money can buy?

Do you want (mostly) outstanding graphics and smooth gameplay?

Do you want a relatively robust amount of unlocks customization options?

Do you want a ridiculous (and I mean ridiculous) roster size?

Do you want to play a plethora of matches from wrestling history?

Do you want a satisfying amount of well-made community content?

Do you want to talk about Tyler Breeze?

This is the game for you

Are you like me and more or less simply want a career mode akin to the old SvR games, with a never ending cycle, branching paths and voice acting?

Do you want a large variety of match types, again akin to the SvR games?

Nooooope


Basically If all you want is a great wrestling sim with plenty of unlocks and historical matches, look no further. You will get hours of fun from this game. But if you want a satisfying career mode or unique match types, you will be often frustrated by this game. The career mode is repetetive and dull and you CAN'T use your character in any mode other than career, even after you retire. And beyond 2k showcase, don't expect to see buried alive matches and really any niche match types.

6.5/10 for me, 9/10 if my negatives don't matter to you

EDIT 03/06/16: The game has been patched and all of the issues I had have been fixed. Now I absolutely recommend this game without hesitation! (Original review)[pastebin.com]

Last year we finally got a WWE licensed wrestling game on PC in over a decade, but it was a fairly mediocore game. 2K16 is a huge step up from that - It reintroduces many features that were missing, has a much larger roster and online is greatly improved.

In fact this is one of my all time favourite pro wrestling games. If you're a fan of the old school Smackdown or N64 games then beware that this is a much more simulation focused game. It's a lot more slow paced and more unforgiving but that allows for more strategic gameplay. With stamina you can't endlessly run away, and you may have to decide to rest a little following a big move rather than hitting another with no stamina left for a quick pin. There's also limited reversals this time and THANK GOD. FINALLY matches aren't just an endless chain of reversals anymore.

If you dislike any of that then everything can be customised; turn off stamina, reversal slots, adjust finisher damage etc. Also this year's game brings back features like Create An Arena and a much improved Create a Wrestler. (You can create females again! Yay!) The roster is massive and includes past and current wrestlers including some from NXT. Entrances are the best I have ever seen and are now completely seemless which allows you to interfere during your opponent's entrance! Awesome!

It still suffers from Yearly Franchise Syndrome™ which includes plenty of minor bugs and glitches and some strange roster ommisions like Sasha Banks and Charlotte even though Blake and Murphy are somehow in the game. And for some reason you can't use your own entrance music even though you could do it in the last gen console games. Commentary is also as bland as ever and feels like it hasn't improved since Smackdown Vs Raw 2006.

However it is entirely modabble! There was tons of great mods last year from updating wrestler's attire and entrances to entirely new arenas, and this year is no exception. Check out Smacktalks[smacktalks.org] for tons of great mods including tutorials on how to mod the game to use your own custom entrance music.[smacktalks.org]

VS CONSOLE
I've played this game previously on the Xbox One. According to the Xbox, I have played at least 264 hours on it.
So how does the PC version stand up to the console version? I think it holds up very well. The game does have a few crashing problems for me, but so did the console version. The PC version also loads up 10x quicker than console. It would literally take a minute or more to load into a match on the console. For PC, it takes about 10 seconds.

GAMEPLAY
If you're looking for an arcade like wrestling game, I'd suggest looking for a different title. But for someone looking to play a wrestling simulation just like the TV show, you will love this game.

The pacing in matches is fairly slow to start off as you perform lock ups. You then transition into your normal grapples, leading into back and forth action. You have limited reversal, so you have to use your reversals wisely. As you get into the big heavy hitting moves, you start to feel the exhaustion as your wrestler fights with every last strength they have. Every time you kick out from a person's finisher, you feel like you're out of breath as you and your opponent can't believe you still have fight left in you. Believe me when I say, you will feel extremely satisfied when you kick out of a finisher without using your resiliency. And honestly, it's hard to get upset after losing a match when you know you put up one h*ll of a show.

CREATIONS
For creations mode, you have a decent variety of things to create. You can create your own Wrestler (Cool looking or just plain wacky), you can create your own title belt, your own arena, your own show, and unlike 2K15, you can create your own Woman Wrestler (or Diva, as WWE likes to call them...). The customization for your wrestlers are very good. I have been able to create some very life like wrestlers, especially with the face import tool (where you can import any face you want and use them for your created wrestler). Create a move-set is still there of course. Create an entrance is better this year, with nearly every wrestler's entrance as an option, as opposed to very little. Unfortunately, still no custom themes (but there are mods for that...)

MYCAREER
Honestly, I played this on the console version and was VERY bored with it. Very rarely have I ever gotten cutscenes and storylines. Aside from the mandatory feud with Tyler Breeze in the beginning. I don't quite have much to say for this mode since I kind of skipped out on it. I'm currently trying to go through it again for PC. So, hopefully I can give you updates on my thoughts for it.

UNIVERSE MODE
Same sh*t as the previous years, nothing has changed, lol. You run your shows, create feuds. Get occasional cutscenes.

reviewText:
People compare this game to WWE 2K15 a lot. Well 2K15 was garbage so I will compare this game to the last decent one, WWE 2K14.

-No Custom Music

-Logo system is overly complicated and public, from using a logo sizing code on a website to downloading your own images from their community creations in order to use them yourself.

-Cannot setup your own title matches in universe mode.

-Many people reporting crashes, especially during entrances.

-Many people reporting low fps, just read through the discussions page.

-SOOOOOOO many items and parts are missing from the Create-a-Wrestler, I'm talking TONS!

-New disfiguration system, what I call their morphing system, has dropped the sliders and is now using a complicated image interface where you move points of the facial image to morph the face. I'm having a hard time just explaining whatever this new limited system is! Oh yeah and you have to edit the front THEN the side of the face, this includes, for example, editing the mouth under two subsections instead of one, making it far less convenient.

-It takes FOREVER to launch / load, and some are even unable to get the game to load at all.

-The new submission system is just weird, I haven't fully grasped it yet so I won't comment about it too much.

Now to be fair, here is a few things I like about the game;

-Giant roster size and they actually have more divas this time. Divas tend to get sidelined, a major failing in 2K14 imo.

-Can create 100 wrestlers (that all look the same because of limited CAW, i know i know, it just bugs me!)

-Much better graphics (but poor optimization for some)

-Of the clothing parts they actually DO have, there is more volume and detail to them making them look more real.

-You can choose a matieral such as metallic, satin, cotton, ect to give your outfits different sheens.

Overall I do not recommend this game because I myself am regretting buying it. If anything, follow it and wait for 2K to address the problems many are having or just wait until it goes on sale / down in price. Its a mainstream game for a mainstream audience that cares more about graphic quality rather than content quality, action over story, stock play over customization, money over innovation. So your typical modern day corporate charged grab bag full of hot air in order to make it look full. Buyer beware!

reviewText:
This game is a high contrast picture. It has some AWESOME game design marred by shitawful implementation that makes the experience on the whole very unenjoyable.

The pros:
- The graphics look quite frankly amazing even on lower settings.
- The roster is humongous.
- The customization options were largely improved over WWE2k15, including the inclusion of custom divas.
- Career mode is fun, but...

The cons:
- The lnput lags. And i don't mean a bit. I mean that a game where your winning or losing a match (escaping a pin) is based on a timing minigame, has a solid half second of input delay. That is unplayable. You can still win if you get used to it, but it's terrible for a company like 2K to not even be able to code a decent input manager.

- Reversals are ♥♥♥♥ing impossible. Let's be real here: nobody knows ALL the moves to this game. There's just too many. Even if they did, they'd not be able to spot which is being done in time for the reversal window to matter. Hence why the input delay, coupled with the fact that sometimes the reversal prompts just refuse to show, or show too early/late, is again a huge problem that needs addressing ASAP. Considering i've read various sources saying it's been there since 2014, i'd not hold my breath for a fix.

- The AI cheats. If you have limited reversals enabled (Don't) the AI will ignore that if you're gaining too much on it. It also kicks out after the second or third finisher in a match. And we're not talking Undertaker versus Sting on PPV here, we're talking jobbers on a normal show night.

- Lip synching in the very few dubbed scenes is comedically bad, but nobody gives a ♥♥♥♥ about that.

In summation: The game designers for this game put a lot of effort into building a simulator. The fact that the match is graded on its entertainment value is an awesome idea that makes losing feel like less of a failure, if you at least managed to get a good rating out of the match, the strategic choices when building a moveset and stats combination are as deep as it gets, then whoever programmed the whole thing took a giant steaming ♥♥♥♥ all over the very obvious effort and ruined it with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI and Input.

Good job 2K.

reviewText:
A massive word of warning if you're interested in creation. Though I've long stopped watching wrestling, I've always had a soft spot for the games. In particular, the creating of wrestlers has always been a rather large attraction and major selling point. However, despite 2K16 having a seemingly very robust creator wrestler, it is let down by one, fatal flaw. You can no longer import or have any sort of custom soundtrack. The music that is already in the game is what you have to use.

Let me repeat that. YOU. CANNOT. HAVE. CUSTOM. ENTRANCE. THEMES.

If you wanted to try and create Alex Wright and have him come out with his WCW theme, forget about it. Wanted to create a character from another game and have them walk out to their theme, nope. Frankly, this is disgraceful and removes a large element of fun from the game.

It might seem like a silly thing to rage about, but I'd wager for a fair few people, this is a big turnoff. Honestly, had I known this, I would have never, EVER, bought the game.

Sadly, I can't even refund it. So I can only look on in sour malcontent as this piece of software squats on my hard drive. Hopefully, some kind soul will create a mod which enable this a critical feature. And the fact I even had to type that sentence is rather obnoxious.

Shame on you, 2K. Shame on you!

*Extended*

This is my first wrestling game since 2K14. I had no idea they'd removed this feature from 2K15, as I avoided that game given all the negative reports. Again, it seems like a silly thing to gripe about, but once you've had the option to have a creation walk out to a certain type of song (be it serious or silly) you don't want to go back. It just help establish an identity for your creation.

I mean, honestly, if I can't have wrestlers walking out looking all serious and moody to the Pokemon tv theme - what is the point?

No long can I have Nintendo vs. Capcom vs. Sega vs. Sony wrestling abominations walking out to their respective themes - le sigh -

I'm sure the game play and mechanics are fine once you've got used to them. But unless they're a return or a massive improvement on the wrestling games from the N64 (No Mercy, Revenge, 2000) then I don't have too much interest in playing the actual game - expect for drunken throwdowns with friends (again, where the entrance's are a major part of the fun).

No, the creation options are what I'm interested in these days and though I'm disappointed that there is no create a story, I can still create a fictional promotion and characters and mess around every now and then (See above). This isn't a serious game for me, I have no interest in the Online. This is purely for me and my friends.

The purpose of this review is for people who are in the same boat as me. If the tools are released for modding (as I'm sure they will be) then by all means, come and have another look and then judge for yourself.

Until such a time, however, beware.

reviewText:
Assuming you have the same issues as me, once you get the optimisation/launch issues sorted (yes, not ideal - took me about 45 mins) the game runs really well.

When you get into it, it's great fun.

Positive:
- Limited reversals: brilliant idea
- Roster size: *huge*
- Match types: lots
- Moves: lots
- Create a...: extremely in-depth. Haven't explored it much yet, but it looks good
- New Day: just because New Day ROCKS.
- You can beat up Nikki Bella with a sledgehammer.
- Sami Zayn and Kevin Owens are pretty much spot on (they're the first match I played - Sami's entrance is brilliant)

Negative:
- No four horsewomen: Yes, another person saying it. The three women in the triple threat at 'Mania, and the NXT women's champion aren't included, and won't be included. Community creations may well cover it - but they shouldn't have to. WWE should be embarrassed about this.
- Some things are a little outdated. Paige is the NXT women's champion, for example. But I guess, with no Bayley... and Emma isn't Evil Emma.
- Amore and Cassady are included, but no Carmella. Same applies to Blake and Murphy - no Alexa. Again, a little bit lacking, considering the depth in other areas.
- I tried to play online, but it couldn't find a match. Whether that's the game's fault, or just that no one's online, I don't know. But I couldn't play against anyone. So I have to give it a negative mark.

I'll update it if I see anything else of interest, or if I manage to get any online games working - but overall, this is a MASSIVE improvement on 2k15, and while £34.99 (or equivalent) is expensive, if you like WWE, and can get it cheaper, it really is a must buy.

See you all in game - hopefully!

First of all let me start by saying that they have definitely made improvements from 2K15, You can feel that in the overall gameplay, You can see that in the added improvement to animations, reversals and general flow to the game.

HOWEVER I have read that there has been a fair amount of criticism levelled at this game since its release, and unfortunately I find it all to be fairly well accurate.
- first and foremost nine times out of 10 the game doesn't load past the Austin screen without fiddling around Ctl, Alt, Dlt, however that will be easily fixed come bug release time.
And then there's the little nitpicking, The games FPS could be better, I'm playing on a GTX 980Ti and sometimes during entrances the frame rate drops dramatically, so that's definitely the game not me.
And then we get to the criticisms levelled towards the game's highly anticipated 'my career mode'
- The post match interview questions are far too vague, oh and it's a constant cycle of three, Yes, The creators of this game only put in a cycle of three different interview questions you can be asked...Evan NBA 2K got it better.
And then there is the My career wrestlers voice, what happens if you are someone with dark skin?
You're forced to have the most whitest sounding voice and it can't be changed.

Yes they made a lot of improvements, and yes I probably would recommend it to a friend, but this game is still far from perfect, and there are quite a lot of bugs that need fixing.

6/10 IGN

My Specs :

i7 3700K @ 3.4ghz
8 gig ram @ 1600mhz
Nvidia GTX 780 Ti

Initial Impressions :

I had the similar issue that's being reported in that I couldn't initally get past the startup splash screen. Despite being a huge Steve Austin fan looking at his shiny chrome head for 5 minutes was a bit much. Luckily the running exe file as admin trick worked out perfectly. Performance :

No complaints from me as I run this game at smooth 60 FPS (1920x1080, max details and MSAA enabled) It's a much more reliable port overall with no weird frame dips like 2K15 had. My only niggling issue would be the entrances/cutscenes being capped at 30 FPS it can be a little jarring.

Gameplay :

It's some how more fun than 2K15 while also being punishing to the player. I've lost a fair few bouts this time round and enjoying the challenge something that's been missing from the series for a while.

Other Thoughts :

Huge roster which I love but why wasn't Bayley included? Soundtrack is a lot more drab than 2K15 and I ended up turning off all menu music. Overall though I feel like I'm going to be pumping many hours into this game and highly recommend this title to all rasslin fans (and maybe those that just want to try a new fighting game)

First of all let me start by saying that they have definitely made improvements from 2K15, You can feel that in the overall gameplay, You can see that in the added improvement to animations, reversals and general flow to the game.

HOWEVER I have read that there has been a fair amount of criticism levelled at this game since its release, and unfortunately I find it all to be fairly well accurate.

And then we get to the criticisms levelled towards the game's highly anticipated 'my career mode'
- The post match interview questions are far too vague, oh and it's a constant cycle of three, Yes, The creators of this game only put in a cycle of three different interview questions you can be asked...Evan NBA 2K got it better.
And then there is the My career wrestlers voice, what happens if you are someone with dark skin?
You're forced to have the most whitest sounding voice and it can't be changed.

Yes they made a lot of improvements, and yes I probably would recommend it to a friend, but this game is still far from perfect, and there are quite a lot of bugs that need fixing.

reviewText: The incredible presentation and amazing roster of characters are somewhat tarnished by the new game mechanics used for pinning and submissions.  Computer opponents will kick out of most pins no matter how battered and bruised they are unless you hit them with a finisher.  This can make matches a grind to build up your momentum bar often more than twice in order to win.  The new submission system is clumsily implemented and caused controller breaking frustration at first.  At least 50% of gamers seem to be having problems with this new system for submissions.  I researched online and found some helpful advice from gamers who understood how to use it successfuly, so persevere if you're having trouble with it!  Overall however the pros far outweigh the cons in my opinion.  The insanely huge roster spans decades of professional wrestling and includes a lot of exciting big names.  Improvements to the 'My Career' mode make it even more exciting and involving than before, in many ways this is the best wrestling sim ever made.  It's a huge improvement over WWE 2K15 and if you forgive the two new clumsy game mechanics you'll enjoy some of the rawest, most realistic and well paced wrestling action ever devised for a computer game.

reviewText:
Contrary to what some are saying about performance, I can confirm that you can absolutely melt your GPU off with insane frame count if you're running a higher end system.

The game runs fabulous for me but I keep V Sync on to stop 3452 fps coil whine from getting out of control.

Pros to this years offering?
Improved CAW, though masks and facepaint still leave a lot to be desired.
Slightly better visuals than last year on PC.
It's a Triple A wrestling game on PC!!!
Game mechanics are improved over the b.s. that was 2k15 (even though I liked that title too)

Cons?
the CAW voice can not be changed and the voiceovers and dialogue leave a LOT to be desired.
Rivalries, while pretty cool, are super repetitive especially in the early stages of your career.
It takes literally for ever to get to main event status (at least in my experience thus far).

Overall the game is really well designed in my opinion, and being able to download smarky ♥♥♥♥ from the 2k creations hub thing is great for any fan of the actual business itself. You can also download and run some pretty well put together CAW's from the hub who look like new WWE additions, or some other indie faves or past wrestlers who did not make it in.
If you've got the cash now go for it. I picked up 2k15 last year for $13.99 but had no trouble getting this years offering on release day for PC at full price.
